page.title: 18Tellisford Landscape.
page.content: The main land use is dairy farming with some wooded areas used for pheasant rearing for profit-making syndicate shoots and private shooting parties. Hedged fields and meadows with some wheat and barley provide the scenery, which has been marred by the death of hundreds of elms, killed in the late 1970's by disease. The river Frome with its ruined mill (recorded in Domesday Book 1086), weir and pathways provide fishing, walking and picnicking for people from nearby towns. Cobbled steps, an old pack horse bridge and footpath cross the valley, allowing no route for vehicles. All other lanes are metalled, steep and narrow, affording no passing places. The village is famous for its peace, with no through traffic, and is visited by artists and naturalists.
